column1: '''''Völuspá''''' ("Prophecy of the Seeress") is the first poem of the ''[[Poetic Edda]]''
column2: a collection of [[Old Norse]] poems. It is preserved whole in two manuscripts
column3: the Codex Regius and the Hauksbók
column4: and partially in Snorri Sturluson's Prose Edda. [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] was influenced greatly by the saga
column5: most obviously in the fact that most of the names of his Dwarves were drawn from it. [[Christopher Tolkien]] suggests that "''those Dwarf-names in The Hobbit provided the whole starting-point for the Mannish languages in Middle-earth.''"<ref>{{PM|II}}
column7: "[http://www.tolkiensociety.org/tolkien/book_reviews_01.html Review: The Peoples of Middle-earth (The History of Middle-earth XII)]" at Tolkiensociety.org. See section "Dwarvish and Mannish Related". Retrieved 30 August 2010.</ref>

column1: Almost all of the names of the [[Dwarves]] of [[Middle-earth]]
column3: are taken from a section of the Völuspá called the ''Dvergatal'' (the "Catalogue of Dwarves").<ref name="Letter25">{{L|25}}</ref><ref group="note">The ''Dvergatal'' is now considered a later interpolation
column4: and is often omitted from newer editions of ''Völuspá''.</ref> The ''Dvergatal'' is contained in stanzas 10–16:

column1: 10. Þar var Móðsognir mæztr of orðinn
14. Mál er dverga í Dvalins liði
þeir er sóttu frá salar steini
þat mun æ uppi meðan öld lifir
10. There was Motsognir | the mightiest made
Many a likeness | of men they made
Regin and Rathsvith-- | the list aright.
14. The race of the dwarfs | in [[Dwalin|Dvalin]]'s throng
Down to [[Lofar]] | the list must I tell;
They sought a home | in the fields of sand.
So for all time | shall the tale be known
The list of all | the forbears of [[Lofar]].
Eikinskjaldi is directly translated to Oakenshield
* [http://www.sacred-texts.com/neu/poe/poe03.htm Völuspá] (English translation by Henry Adams Bellows)
